description: The first and most fundamental technique in Aikido. Ikkyo teaches the basic principle of leading and controlling an attacker's center through arm manipulation.

key_postures.title: Ai-hanmi Kamae
key_postures.description: Begin in matching stance with your partner. Maintain proper distance (ma-ai) with your lead foot aligned with your partner's lead foot. Your body should be relaxed yet alert.

key_postures.title: Irimi Entry
key_postures.description: As uke attacks, blend with the movement by entering deeply alongside their arm. Your front hand connects to their elbow while your back hand guides their wrist.

key_postures.title: Osae (Pin)
key_postures.description: Guide uke down to the mat in a spiral motion. The final pin positions uke face-down with their arm extended, elbow controlled, and shoulder locked.

important_notes.note: Never use force against force. Ikkyo works through proper timing and angle, not muscular strength.
Keep your center connected to uke's center throughout the technique. If you lose this connection, the technique becomes ineffective.
The cutting motion should originate from your hips, not your arms. Think of it as a sword cut (tegatana).

characteristics.feature: Ikkyo develops the foundational understanding of controlling through the elbow joint.
This technique can be applied from virtually any attack, making it extremely versatile.

description: The second teaching introduces wrist control through a precise joint lock. Nikyo develops sensitivity to pressure and angle while maintaining connection.

key_postures.title: Grip Establishment
key_postures.description: After blending with uke's attack, secure a C-grip on their wrist. Your thumb should be on the back of their hand, fingers wrapped around the wrist.

key_postures.title: Wrist Rotation
key_postures.description: Rotate uke's wrist inward while maintaining elbow control. The rotation should be smooth and continuous, not jerky.

key_postures.title: Kneeling Pin
key_postures.description: Bring uke down using the wrist lock, transitioning to a kneeling position. The final pin secures both the wrist and elbow.

important_notes.note: The effectiveness of nikyo comes from precise angle, not crushing force. Find the correct angle and the technique requires minimal effort.
Always maintain control of uke's elbow. Without elbow control, uke can escape the wrist lock.

characteristics.feature: Nikyo teaches precise joint manipulation and sensitivity to your partner's structure.
The pain compliance element requires careful application in training to prevent injury.

description: The third teaching uses a rotational wrist lock that spirals through the entire arm to the shoulder. Sankyo embodies the spiral nature of Aikido movement.

key_postures.title: Hand Capture
key_postures.description: Capture uke's hand with both hands, creating a structure where your fingers wrap over their hand and your thumbs press into their palm.

key_postures.title: Spiral Rotation
key_postures.description: Rotate uke's hand in a spiral motion toward their centerline. Their elbow should rise as the rotation continues.

key_postures.title: Standing Control
key_postures.description: Maintain the lock while transitioning to various positions. Sankyo can lead to throws or pins depending on the situation.

important_notes.note: The spiral must be continuous and connected to your center movement. Isolated hand manipulation is ineffective.
Watch for over-rotation which can cause wrist injury. Apply the lock smoothly and give uke time to tap.

characteristics.feature: Sankyo exemplifies the spiral energy (kokyu) central to Aikido's effectiveness.
This technique is particularly effective for weapon disarms and multiple attacker situations.

description: A fundamental throwing technique that can project an attacker in any of the four cardinal directions. Shihonage teaches proper body rotation and timing.

key_postures.title: Katate-dori Grasp
key_postures.description: From a same-side wrist grab, blend with uke's energy while securing their wrist with both hands.

key_postures.title: Tenkan Pivot
key_postures.description: Execute a 180-degree pivot while raising uke's arm overhead. Your movement should be under uke's arm, not forcing their arm over.

key_postures.title: Throw Completion
key_postures.description: Complete the throw by cutting down with uke's arm while stepping through. Uke falls backward in a controlled manner.

important_notes.note: Your pivot must bring you completely under uke's arm. Partial rotation results in a weak or dangerous technique.
The throw comes from your hip rotation, not from pulling uke's arm. Let your body movement create the throw.

characteristics.feature: Shihonage develops spatial awareness and the ability to redirect energy in any direction.
The versatility of this technique makes it applicable to multiple attacks and situations.

description: A powerful entering technique that embodies the principle of irimi - moving directly into and through an attack. Often called the 'twenty-year technique' due to its depth.

key_postures.title: Initial Entry
key_postures.description: Enter deeply past uke's attack, positioning yourself alongside them with your hip connected to their center.

key_postures.title: Spiral Drawing
key_postures.description: Draw uke's balance in a circular motion, lowering their center while maintaining connection through your arm and body.

key_postures.title: Final Throw
key_postures.description: Complete the throw by entering again while your arm guides uke's head and neck backward in a controlled manner.

important_notes.note: True irimi requires complete commitment. Half-hearted entry leaves you vulnerable to counter-attack.
The throw should feel like a wave - uke is drawn in, then projected out. Never force the technique.

characteristics.feature: Iriminage develops courage and the ability to move into danger rather than away from it.
This technique requires excellent timing and connection, making it a lifelong study.

description: The first and most fundamental sword swing in Aiki-ken practice. This exercise develops proper cutting form, breath coordination, and center movement.

key_postures.title: Chudan Kamae
key_postures.description: Begin in middle guard position with the sword tip at throat height. Grip should be relaxed but firm, with hands properly spaced on the handle.

key_postures.title: Raise (Furikaburi)
key_postures.description: Raise the sword overhead in a large arc. The tip should travel past your center line, and your arms should be relaxed throughout the movement.

key_postures.title: Cut (Kirioroshi)
key_postures.description: Execute the downward cut by dropping your center and letting gravity assist the motion. Stop with the tip at knee height.

important_notes.note: The cut must come from your center, not your arms. Your body drops, and the sword follows.
Coordinate your breath with the movement: inhale on the raise, exhale on the cut.

characteristics.feature: Suburi practice develops the fundamental body mechanics used in all Aikido techniques.
Regular sword training strengthens the connection between breath, movement, and intention.

description: The first paired sword kata in Iwama Aiki-ken. This practice develops timing, distance, and the ability to read an opponent's intention.

key_postures.title: Opening Position
key_postures.description: Both partners begin in chudan kamae at proper distance (issoku itto no ma). Eye contact and awareness are maintained throughout.

key_postures.title: Attack and Response
key_postures.description: Uchitachi initiates with a shomen cut. Uketachi receives by raising their sword and blending with the incoming energy.

key_postures.title: Counter and Conclusion
key_postures.description: Uketachi completes the kata with a decisive counter-cut while uchitachi accepts the technique and yields.

important_notes.note: Uchitachi's role is to provide sincere attacks that develop uketachi's ability. Never hold back or 'let' your partner win.
The kata should flow naturally once learned. Hesitation or rushing both indicate areas for improvement.

characteristics.feature: Kumitachi develops maai (distance) and de-ai (meeting timing) essential for all martial practice.
Partner sword practice creates an understanding of weapons that directly informs empty-hand techniques.

description: The first staff swing exercise. Jo practice in Iwama style develops circular movement, both-handed coordination, and flowing energy.

key_postures.title: Choku-tsuki Kamae
key_postures.description: Hold the jo with both hands, rear hand near the end, front hand about one-third from the tip. Body faces forward with the jo pointing at the opponent's throat.

key_postures.title: Thrust Preparation
key_postures.description: Draw the jo back along your center line while shifting weight to the rear foot. The jo remains level throughout this movement.

key_postures.title: Thrust Execution
key_postures.description: Drive forward with the rear foot while extending the jo in a straight thrust. Power comes from the hips, not the arms.

important_notes.note: The thrust and footwork must be unified. Arriving before or after your weapon creates openings.
Maintain awareness of the entire jo length. The rear end is also a weapon.

characteristics.feature: Jo practice develops the ability to project power in a straight line - essential for atemi in taijutsu.
The jo's length requires full-body coordination that transfers directly to empty-hand technique.

description: The foundational jo kata of Iwama Aikido, consisting of 31 movements. This kata embodies the principles of Riai - the integration of jo, ken, and taijutsu.

key_postures.title: Opening Sequence
key_postures.description: The kata begins with a choku-tsuki followed by a series of strikes and thrusts that establish the rhythm and flow of the practice.

key_postures.title: Middle Section
key_postures.description: The middle section includes more complex combinations including kaeshi-tsuki (returning thrust) and various striking patterns.

key_postures.title: Closing Sequence
key_postures.description: The kata concludes with decisive movements that demonstrate all the principles practiced throughout, ending in proper zanshin.

important_notes.note: Learn each movement individually before attempting to flow through the entire kata. Quality over speed.
Every movement in the kata has a martial application. Practice with awareness of imaginary opponents.
The 31 Jo Kata should be practiced both solo and with the 31 Kumijo (paired practice) to fully understand the applications.

characteristics.feature: This kata was developed by O-Sensei in Iwama and represents his mature understanding of jo work.
Mastery of the 31 Jo Kata demonstrates understanding of distance, timing, and flowing energy essential to Iwama style.

description: The fundamental seated exercise that develops kokyu-ryoku (breath power). This practice is typically done at the end of every class.

key_postures.title: Seiza Position
key_postures.description: Both partners sit in seiza facing each other. Uke grabs both of nage's wrists firmly. Maintain upright posture and calm breathing.

key_postures.title: Extension
key_postures.description: Nage extends arms forward and upward while maintaining relaxed shoulders. The power comes from the lower abdomen (hara), not arm strength.

key_postures.title: Projection
key_postures.description: Continue the extension to unbalance uke and guide them backward to the mat. The movement should be smooth and continuous.

important_notes.note: Relax your shoulders completely. Tension blocks the flow of power from your center.
Breathe naturally throughout. Holding your breath creates stiffness and weakness.

characteristics.feature: Kokyu-ho teaches the fundamental principle of extending energy without muscular force.
Regular practice develops the 'internal strength' that makes advanced techniques possible.
